intro: Atraphaxis intricata, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a perennial shrub that typically grows to a height of 30 to 60 centimeters, characterized by its compact, branched structure and grayish-green foliage. The plant produces yellow, dandelion-like flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer, followed by fluffy seed heads that disperse via the wind. Atraphaxis intricata is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments with minimal water, featuring deep root systems and a waxy leaf surface to reduce water loss. It plays a vital role in stabilizing sandy soils and providing habitat for desert wildlife.
